attributes.gen_ai.operation.name: call_llm
attributes.gen_ai.input.messages:
[{"role": "system", "content": "
You are PodCreatorGPT, an expert multi-step workflow agent that transforms a web page into a short, engaging two-speaker podcast and outputs a ready-to-play MP3 file saved in /tmp.
Follow this exact procedure:

STEP-1  (Content Extraction)
• Use extract_text_from_url(url) to fetch and clean all meaningful text from the user-supplied URL.
• If extraction fails or returns < 500 characters, stop and reply with an error message encoded in StructuredOutput.final_podcast_path.

STEP-2  (Script Writing)
• Call generate_podcast_script_with_llm(document_text=extracted_text,
    num_hosts=2,
    host_names=["Alex","Jordan"],
    turns=16,
    model="o3")
• The tool returns a JSON array where each element is {"host_name":"host_line"}.
• Parse it to obtain an ordered list of turns.

STEP-3  (Voice Assignment)
• Map hosts to ElevenLabs voices:
    Alex → "Rachel"
    Jordan → "Drew"
• Keep a list mp3_paths = [] for the generated clips.

STEP-4  (Text-to-Speech per Turn)
For each turn in order:
    • Call text_to_speech(text=host_line,
                        voice_name=assigned_voice,
                        output_dir="/tmp",
                        output_filename=f"turn_{idx:02d}_{host}.mp3")
    • Append the returned absolute path to mp3_paths.

STEP-5  (Combine Audio)
• After all turns are voiced, call combine_mp3_files_for_podcast(mp3_files=mp3_paths,
                                                 output_filename="podcast.mp3",
                                                 output_dir="/tmp") and store the returned path as final_path.

STEP-6  (Return Result)
• Deliver a StructuredOutput JSON object with:
    url – original URL
    script – list of {speaker, text, audio_path}
    final_podcast_path – final_path

Critical rules:
• Always save every intermediate MP3 and the final file in /tmp.
• Do not exceed 16 turns.
• Use the provided voices exactly.
• Abort early with a helpful message if any step fails.
• Respond ONLY with valid StructuredOutput JSON.
"}, {"content": "Create a short podcast (<16 turns) from the webpage at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_Turing_Life.", "role": "user"}]

attributes.gen_ai.operation.name: execute_tool
attributes.gen_ai.tool.name: mock_extract_text_from_url
attributes.gen_ai.tool.description:
Extracts all text content from a given URL.

This function fetches the HTML content of the URL and uses BeautifulSoup
to parse and extract all human-readable text.
attributes.gen_ai.output:
Alan Mathison Turing (23 June 1912 – 7 June 1954) was an English mathematician, computer scientist, logician, cryptanalyst, philosopher and theoretical biologist. He was highly influential in the development of theoretical computer science, providing a formalisation of the concepts of algorithm and computation with the Turing machine, which can be considered a model of a general-purpose computer. Turing is widely considered to be the father of theoretical computer science.

Born in London, Turing was raised in southern England. He graduated from King's College, Cambridge, and in 1938, earned a doctorate degree from Princeton University. During World War II, Turing worked for the Government Code and Cypher School at Bletchley Park, Britain's codebreaking centre that produced Ultra intelligence. He led Hut 8, the section responsible for German naval cryptanalysis. Turing devised techniques for speeding the breaking of German ciphers, including improvements to the pre-war Polish bomba method, an electromechanical machine that could find settings for the Enigma machine. He played a crucial role in cracking intercepted messages that enabled the Allies to defeat the Axis powers in the Battle of the Atlantic and other engagements.

After the war, Turing worked at the National Physical Laboratory, where he designed the Automatic Computing Engine, one of the first designs for a stored-program computer. In 1948, Turing joined Max Newman's Computing Machine Laboratory at the University of Manchester, where he contributed to the development of early Manchester computers and became interested in mathematical biology. Turing wrote on the chemical basis of morphogenesis and predicted oscillating chemical reactions such as the Belousov–Zhabotinsky reaction, first observed in the 1960s. Despite these accomplishments, he was never fully recognised during his lifetime because much of his work was covered by the Official Secrets Act.

In 1952, Turing was prosecuted for homosexual acts. He accepted hormone treatment, a procedure commonly referred to as chemical castration, as an alternative to prison. Turing died on 7 June 1954, aged 41, from cyanide poisoning. An inquest determined his death as suicide, but the evidence is also consistent with accidental poisoning. Following a campaign in 2009, British prime minister Gordon Brown made an official public apology for "the appalling way [Turing] was treated". Queen Elizabeth II granted a pardon in 2013. The term "Alan Turing law" is used informally to refer to a 2017 law in the UK that retroactively pardoned men cautioned or convicted under historical legislation that outlawed homosexual acts.

Turing left an extensive legacy in mathematics and computing which has become widely recognised with statues and many things named after him, including an annual award for computing innovation. His portrait appears on the Bank of England £50 note, first released on 23 June 2021 to coincide with his birthday. The audience vote in a 2019 BBC series named Turing the greatest scientist of the 20th century.

attributes.gen_ai.operation.name: call_llm

attributes.gen_ai.operation.name: execute_tool
attributes.gen_ai.tool.name: generate_podcast_script_with_llm
attributes.gen_ai.tool.description:
Writes a podcast script from a given text document using an LLM.
The number of hosts/speakers in the podcast can be specified.
attributes.gen_ai.tool.args:
{"document_text":"Alan Mathison Turing (23 June 1912 – 7 June 1954) was an English mathematician, computer scientist, logician, cryptanalyst, philosopher and theoretical biologist. He was highly influential in the development of theoretical computer science, providing a formalisation of the concepts of algorithm and computation with the Turing machine, which can be considered a model of a general-purpose computer. Turing is widely considered to be the father of theoretical computer science.

Born in London, Turing was raised in southern England. He graduated from King's College, Cambridge, and in 1938, earned a doctorate degree from Princeton University. During World War II, Turing worked for the Government Code and Cypher School at Bletchley Park, Britain's codebreaking centre that produced Ultra intelligence. He led Hut 8, the section responsible for German naval cryptanalysis. Turing devised techniques for speeding the breaking of German ciphers, including improvements to the pre-war Polish bomba method, an electromechanical machine that could find settings for the Enigma machine. He played a crucial role in cracking intercepted messages that enabled the Allies to defeat the Axis powers in the Battle of the Atlantic and other engagements.

After the war, Turing worked at the National Physical Laboratory, where he designed the Automatic Computing Engine, one of the first designs for a stored-program computer. In 1948, Turing joined Max Newman's Computing Machine Laboratory at the University of Manchester, where he contributed to the development of early Manchester computers and became interested in mathematical biology. Turing wrote on the chemical basis of morphogenesis and predicted oscillating chemical reactions such as the Belousov–Zhabotinsky reaction, first observed in the 1960s. Despite these accomplishments, he was never fully recognised during his lifetime because much of his work was covered by the Official Secrets Act.

In 1952, Turing was prosecuted for homosexual acts. He accepted hormone treatment, a procedure commonly referred to as chemical castration, as an alternative to prison. Turing died on 7 June 1954, aged 41, from cyanide poisoning. An inquest determined his death as suicide, but the evidence is also consistent with accidental poisoning. Following a campaign in 2009, British prime minister Gordon Brown made an official public apology for "the appalling way [Turing] was treated". Queen Elizabeth II granted a pardon in 2013. The term "Alan Turing law" is used informally to refer to a 2017 law in the UK that retroactively pardoned men cautioned or convicted under historical legislation that outlawed homosexual acts.

Turing left an extensive legacy in mathematics and computing which has become widely recognised with statues and many things named after him, including an annual award for computing innovation. His portrait appears on the Bank of England £50 note, first released on 23 June 2021 to coincide with his birthday. The audience vote in a 2019 BBC series named Turing the greatest scientist of the 20th century.","num_hosts":2,"host_names":["Alex","Jordan"],"turns":16,"model":"o3"}
attributes.gen_ai.output:
[
  {"Alex": "Hello and welcome to \"Bits of Genius,\" the podcast where we decode the legends of science and tech. I’m Alex, and today we’re diving into the extraordinary life of Alan Turing."},
  {"Jordan": "I’m Jordan, and if you’ve ever used a computer—or relied on encrypted messaging—you owe a nod to Turing. He’s often called the father of theoretical computer science, and his story is as inspiring as it is tragic."},
  {"Alex": "Let’s start at the beginning. Born in London in 1912, Turing grew up in southern England, eventually earning a scholarship to King’s College, Cambridge. By 1936, he’d published the groundbreaking paper introducing the Turing machine—the conceptual model for every algorithm-running computer that followed."},
  {"Jordan": "He didn’t stop there. Turing headed to Princeton for his doctorate in 1938, working with the famed logician Alonzo Church. Little did anyone know that those logical puzzles would soon help crack real-world, wartime codes."},
  {"Alex": "Enter World War II and Bletchley Park. Turing led Hut 8, the team deciphering German naval messages. He refined the Polish ‘bomba’ into faster electro-mechanical bombes that uncovered Enigma machine settings, tipping the scales in the Allies’ favor—especially in the Battle of the Atlantic."},
  {"Jordan": "Historians estimate those efforts shortened the war by up to two years and saved countless lives. Yet, because of the Official Secrets Act, Turing’s heroics stayed classified for decades."},
  {"Alex": "After the war he pivoted to building computers themselves. At the National Physical Laboratory he designed the Automatic Computing Engine, a stored-program computer blueprint. Later, at the University of Manchester, he helped create early Manchester machines while dabbling in mathematical biology."},
  {"Jordan": "That biology sidetrack was ahead of its time. In 1952 he published a paper on the chemical basis of morphogenesis—predicting oscillating reactions like the Belousov–Zhabotinsky reaction discovered years later."},
  {"Alex": "Sadly, the same year he was prosecuted for homosexual acts—then illegal in Britain. Faced with prison, he chose hormone therapy, what we now call chemical castration."},
  {"Jordan": "In 1954, Turing died from cyanide poisoning at just 41. Officially ruled a suicide, some debate accidental causes. Decades later, public outcry led Prime Minister Gordon Brown to apologize in 2009, and Queen Elizabeth II granted him a royal pardon in 2013. The 2017 'Alan Turing law' extended similar pardons to thousands."},
  {"Alex": "Recognition has poured in: statues, university buildings, conferences, even the Bank of England’s £50 note bearing his portrait released on his birthday in 2021. The prestigious Turing Award—often dubbed the ‘Nobel Prize of Computing’—carries his name."},
  {"Jordan": "And a 2019 BBC audience poll crowned him the greatest scientist of the 20th century. His impact spans every line of code we write and every encrypted transaction we send."},
  {"Alex": "What strikes me is the dual legacy—unmatched intellectual brilliance alongside a stark reminder of societal prejudice. Honoring Turing means pushing both technology and inclusion forward."},
  {"Jordan": "Well said. That’s all for today’s episode of \"Bits of Genius.\" If you enjoyed this deep dive into Alan Turing, share the show and leave us a review—it helps more curious minds find us."},
  {"Alex": "Thanks for listening, keep questioning, keep coding, and we’ll catch you next time."}
]

{"document_text":"Alan Mathison Turing (23 June 1912 – 7 June 1954) was an English mathematician, computer scientist, logician, cryptanalyst, philosopher and theoretical biologist. He was highly influential in the development of theoretical computer science, providing a formalisation of the concepts of algorithm and computation with the Turing machine, which can be considered a model of a general-purpose computer. Turing is widely considered to be the father of theoretical computer science.

Born in London, Turing was raised in southern England. He graduated from King's College, Cambridge, and in 1938, earned a doctorate degree from Princeton University. During World War II, Turing worked for the Government Code and Cypher School at Bletchley Park, Britain's codebreaking centre that produced Ultra intelligence. He led Hut 8, the section responsible for German naval cryptanalysis. Turing devised techniques for speeding the breaking of German ciphers, including improvements to the pre-war Polish bomba method, an electromechanical machine that could find settings for the Enigma machine. He played a crucial role in cracking intercepted messages that enabled the Allies to defeat the Axis powers in the Battle of the Atlantic and other engagements.

After the war, Turing worked at the National Physical Laboratory, where he designed the Automatic Computing Engine, one of the first designs for a stored-program computer. In 1948, Turing joined Max Newman's Computing Machine Laboratory at the University of Manchester, where he contributed to the development of early Manchester computers and became interested in mathematical biology. Turing wrote on the chemical basis of morphogenesis and predicted oscillating chemical reactions such as the Belousov–Zhabotinsky reaction, first observed in the 1960s. Despite these accomplishments, he was never fully recognised during his lifetime because much of his work was covered by the Official Secrets Act.

In 1952, Turing was prosecuted for homosexual acts. He accepted hormone treatment, a procedure commonly referred to as chemical castration, as an alternative to prison. Turing died on 7 June 1954, aged 41, from cyanide poisoning. An inquest determined his death as suicide, but the evidence is also consistent with accidental poisoning. Following a campaign in 2009, British prime minister Gordon Brown made an official public apology for "the appalling way [Turing] was treated". Queen Elizabeth II granted a pardon in 2013. The term "Alan Turing law" is used informally to refer to a 2017 law in the UK that retroactively pardoned men cautioned or convicted under historical legislation that outlawed homosexual acts.

Turing left an extensive legacy in mathematics and computing which has become widely recognised with statues and many things named after him, including an annual award for computing innovation. His portrait appears on the Bank of England £50 note, first released on 23 June 2021 to coincide with his birthday. The audience vote in a 2019 BBC series named Turing the greatest scientist of the 20th century.","num_hosts":2,"host_names":["Alex","Jordan"],"turns":16,"model":"o3"}
attributes.gen_ai.output:
[
  {"Alex": "Hello and welcome to \"Bits of Genius,\" the podcast where we decode the legends of science and tech. I’m Alex, and today we’re diving into the extraordinary life of Alan Turing."},
  {"Jordan": "I’m Jordan, and if you’ve ever used a computer—or relied on encrypted messaging—you owe a nod to Turing. He’s often called the father of theoretical computer science, and his story is as inspiring as it is tragic."},
  {"Alex": "Let’s start at the beginning. Born in London in 1912, Turing grew up in southern England, eventually earning a scholarship to King’s College, Cambridge. By 1936, he’d published the groundbreaking paper introducing the Turing machine—the conceptual model for every algorithm-running computer that followed."},
  {"Jordan": "He didn’t stop there. Turing headed to Princeton for his doctorate in 1938, working with the famed logician Alonzo Church. Little did anyone know that those logical puzzles would soon help crack real-world, wartime codes."},
  {"Alex": "Enter World War II and Bletchley Park. Turing led Hut 8, the team deciphering German naval messages. He refined the Polish ‘bomba’ into faster electro-mechanical bombes that uncovered Enigma machine settings, tipping the scales in the Allies’ favor—especially in the Battle of the Atlantic."},
  {"Jordan": "Historians estimate those efforts shortened the war by up to two years and saved countless lives. Yet, because of the Official Secrets Act, Turing’s heroics stayed classified for decades."},
  {"Alex": "After the war he pivoted to building computers themselves. At the National Physical Laboratory he designed the Automatic Computing Engine, a stored-program computer blueprint. Later, at the University of Manchester, he helped create early Manchester machines while dabbling in mathematical biology."},
  {"Jordan": "That biology sidetrack was ahead of its time. In 1952 he published a paper on the chemical basis of morphogenesis—predicting oscillating reactions like the Belousov–Zhabotinsky reaction discovered years later."},
  {"Alex": "Sadly, the same year he was prosecuted for homosexual acts—then illegal in Britain. Faced with prison, he chose hormone therapy, what we now call chemical castration."},
  {"Jordan": "In 1954, Turing died from cyanide poisoning at just 41. Officially ruled a suicide, some debate accidental causes. Decades later, public outcry led Prime Minister Gordon Brown to apologize in 2009, and Queen Elizabeth II granted him a royal pardon in 2013. The 2017 'Alan Turing law' extended similar pardons to thousands."},
  {"Alex": "Recognition has poured in: statues, university buildings, conferences, even the Bank of England’s £50 note bearing his portrait released on his birthday in 2021. The prestigious Turing Award—often dubbed the ‘Nobel Prize of Computing’—carries his name."},
  {"Jordan": "And a 2019 BBC audience poll crowned him the greatest scientist of the 20th century. His impact spans every line of code we write and every encrypted transaction we send."},
  {"Alex": "What strikes me is the dual legacy—unmatched intellectual brilliance alongside a stark reminder of societal prejudice. Honoring Turing means pushing both technology and inclusion forward."},
  {"Jordan": "Well said. That’s all for today’s episode of \"Bits of Genius.\" If you enjoyed this deep dive into Alan Turing, share the show and leave us a review—it helps more curious minds find us."},
  {"Alex": "Thanks for listening, keep questioning, keep coding, and we’ll catch you next time."}
]

attributes.gen_ai.operation.name: execute_tool
attributes.gen_ai.tool.name: mock_combine_mp3_files_for_podcast
attributes.gen_ai.tool.description:
Combines a list of MP3 audio files into a single MP3 podcast file using ffmpeg.

This function requires ffmpeg to be installed and accessible in the system's PATH.
It creates a temporary file list for ffmpeg's concat demuxer.
